name: ANA - ML
tagline: Towards a Modelling Framework for Adaptive Normative Agents
body:
Identifying Architectural Problems through Prioritization of Code Smells

Authors: Santiago Vidal, Everton Guimaraes, Willian Oizumi, Alessandro Garcia, Andres Diaz and Claudia Marcos

Contact: svidal add exa.unicen.edu.ar

Table of Contents

This web page presents the supplementary material of the paper Identifying Architectural Problems through Prioritization of Code Smells, which has been submitted to the 19th Brazilian Symposium on Software Components, Architectures, and Reuse (SBCARS'16). Complementary information regarding the paper is divided among the sections following:
  1. Code Anomalies and Architecture. Presents the list of code anomalies and architecture problems that we used in the study.
  2. Target Applications. Presents a brief introduction to the target application selected for this study . were presented nor were fully described in the paper.
  3. Agglomerations vs Architectural problems. Presents the correspondence between the agglomerations and the architectural problems observed in the sected target applications.
  4. Data Collection Results. Presents the links to download the spreadsheets containing all the information used in the data analysis (e.g. concerns, scenarios).
  5. Full Paper: presents the link to download a file with the full text of this paper.

1. Code Anomalies and Architectural Problems

Code anomaly, [1], popularly known as a "code smell", is a micro-structure in the program that represents a surface indication of a design problem. In this study, we have focus on 10 types of code anomalies (see Marinescu [2]). We present the definition of the code anomalies following:

  • Brain Class. Complex class that accumulates intelligence by brain methods
  • Brain Method. Long and complex method that centralizes the intelligence of a class
  • Data Class. Class that contains data but not behavior related to the data
  • Disperse Coupling. Method that calls one or few methods of several classes
  • Feature Envy. Method that calls more methods of single external class that their
  • God Class. Long and complex class that centralizes the intelligence of the system
  • Intensive Coupling. Method that calls several methods that are implemented in one or few
  • Refused Parent Bequest. Subclass that does not use the protected methods of its superclass
  • Shotgun Surgery. Method called by many methods that are implemented in different classes
  • Tradition Breaker. Subclass that does not specialize the superclass
    • Architecture problems are structures that indicate violation of intended design rules or fundamental design principles, and negatively impact design quality. In this study we focused on 7 architectural problems, described following.

    Architecture Erosion

  • Ambiguous Interface. Interface that offers only a single, general entry-point but provides two or more services.
  • Concern Overload. Component that is responsible for realizing two or more unrelated system's concerns.
  • Connector Envy. Component that encompasses extensive interaction-related functionality that should be delegated to a connector.
  • Cyclic Dependency. Components that either directly or indirectly depend on each other to function properly..
  • Scattered Functionality. Multiple components responsible for realizing the same high-level concern, with some of them responsible for orthogonal concerns.
  • Unused Interface. Interface that is never used by external modules.

    • Architecture Drift

  • Architectural Violations. Element or relationship that is in the actual architecture but is not in the intended architecture, or vice versa.

    • 2. Target Applications

    In order to conduct this study, we selected 4 target applications as described in the following:

  • Health Watcher is a web-based application that allows citizens to register complaints about health issues in public institution.
  • Mobile Media is software product line to derive applications that manipulate photos, videos and music on mobile devices.
  • SubscribersDB is a large software system of a publishing house. It manages data related with the subscribers of its publications and it supports complex queries on several types of data.
  • Apache OODT is a data-grid system aimed at supporting the management and storage of scientific data.

    • These applications were chosen because they met a number of relevant criteria. First, they are non-trivial systems and their sizes (varying from 10 to 186 KLOC) are manageable for an in-depth analysis of code smells. Second, these applications have been evaluated in other studies regarding design problems ([3], [4], [5], [6], [7],[8]). Finally, the original developers were available to validate the detection strategies for the code smells as well as the architectural problems observed for each version.

    Table 1 summarizes the characteristics of the 4 target applications selected for our study. When applying the Concern Occurrence criterion we selected specific versions of each target application, as follows: Mobile Media (version 5), Health Watcher (version 8) and SubscribersDB (version 2.4). It is important to say that the more representative versions of the target applications were selected, meaning they have a more stable architecture and comprises the most important features implemented.

    Table 1. Characteristics of the selected target applications
    Application Mobile Media Health Watcher SubscribersDB Apache OODT
    System Type SPL Web Web Middleware
    Programming Language Java Java Java Java
    Architecture Style MVC Layers MVC Layers
    Selected Versions 1 to 8 1 to 10 0.2 to 2.4 10
    # KLOC 54 49 10 182
    # Code Smells 260 497 82 1816
    # Classes 77 125 151 1424
    # Agglomerations 16 11 22 431

    5. Correspondence between Agglomerations and Architecture Smells

    In order to better understand how code the relationship between code anomalies and architectural problems, Tables 2 and 3 represents, respectively: (i) single instances - number of code anomalies only related with a problem; and (ii) agglomerations - number of architectural problems related with agglomerations. The results are represented, respectively, for the Health Watcher and Mobile Media systems.

    Table 2. Architectural Problems - Single Code Anomalies Instances vs. Agglomerations (Health Watcher)

    Intensive Coupling healthwatcher.data.rdb 7 Intensive Coupling healthwatcher.data.rdb 7
    Divergent Changes, God Class, Long Method ComplaintRepositoryRDB 7 Divergent Changes, God Class, Long Method ComplaintRepositoryRDB 7
    Divergent Change, Shotgun Surgery DiseaseTypeRepositoryRDB 7 Divergent Change, Shotgun Surgery DiseaseTypeRepositoryRDB 7
    Refused Parent Bequest Complaint 7 Refused Parent Bequest Complaint 7
    Feature Envy healthwatcher.data.rdb 7 Feature Envy healthwatcher.data.rdb 7
    Dispersed Coupling healthwatcher.data.rdb 7 Dispersed Coupling healthwatcher.data.rdb 7

    In order to prioritize the agglomerations of the code anomalies according to the different criteria proposed in this study, we simply ask JSpIRIT to apply the scoring strategy (see Section 4 in the paper manuscript). Therefore, for each selected target application the applications are ranked according to the scoring value. For instance, Table 4 summarizes the ranking of agglomerations for the SubscriberDB system produced by JSpIRIT using the different criteria, namely: history, concern ocurrences (CO), and cancer (CA). For more information and discussions about the results observed for the different criteria please refer to the paper (see the link below for downloading full paper).

    Table 4. Correlation Analysis using different prioritization criteria (Subscriber DB)

    7. Full Paper

    The full paper submitted to the 13th Working IEEE/IFIP Conference on Software Architecture (SBCARS'16) can be downloaded here.

    Further readings about the paper accepted at the International Conference on Software Engineering (ICSE'16) can be found here here.

    References

    1. M. Fowler. Refactoring: Improving the Design of Existing Code. Addison-Wesley, Boston, MA, USA, 1999.

    2. M. Marinescu. Detecting Design Flaws via Metrics in Object-Oriented Systems.TOOLS, Vol. 39, pp.173-182, 2001.

    3. W. Oizumi, A. Garcia, L. da Silva Sousa, B. Cafeo, and Y. Zhao. Code anomalies flock together: Exploring code anomaly agglomerations for locating design problems. in Proceedings of ICSE'16, May, 2016 (To appear).

    4. E. Guimaraes, A. Garcia, and Y. Cai. Exploring blueprints on the prioritization of architecturally relevant code anomalies. in Proceedings of COMPSAC'14, 2014.

    5. S. Vidal, C. Marcos, and J. A. Diaz Pace. An approach to prioritize code smells for refactoring. Automated Software Engineering, pp. 1-32, 2014

    6. T. J. Young. Using aspectj to build a software product line for mobile devices. Ph.D. dissertation, The University of British Columbia, 2005.

    7. S. Soares, E. Laureano, and P. Borba. Implementing distribution and persistence aspects with Aspectj. in ACM Sigplan Notices, 2002.

    8. E. Guimaraes, A. Garcia and Y, Cai. Architecture-Sensitive Heuristics for Prioritizing Critical Code Anomalies. In proceedings of MODULARITY'15, Fort Collins, Colorado, 2015.
